name: Amoxapine (Asendin)
summary: A tetracyclic antidepressant with combined norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake inhibition, as well as dopamine receptor antagonism.
description: Amoxapine is a tetracyclic antidepressant structurally related to dibenzoxazepines. It inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin and also has dopamine receptor antagonist activity, giving it some antipsychotic properties. It was formerly marketed under the brand name Asendin for depression, especially with associated anxiety or psychotic features. Its use has declined due to the risk of tardive dyskinesia and the availability of newer, safer antidepressants.

sections.text: Inhibits norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake transporters, increasing monoamine levels in the synaptic cleft, and blocks dopamine D2 receptors, producing antipsychotic effects.

adult.titrate: Increase gradually by 50 mg every few days as tolerated

sections.geriatric: Start at lower doses (25–50 mg/day) due to sensitivity to side effects
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use with caution; reduced clearance possible

sections.text: Antidepressant effects may appear within 2–4 weeks; antipsychotic effects may occur within days to weeks.

sections.black_box: Antidepressants increase the risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults.

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; neonatal withdrawal possible.
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause sedation in infant.
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of sedation, falls, and cognitive impairment.

sections.text: Reduce dose gradually over 1–2 weeks to avoid withdrawal and rebound symptoms.

items: Unique among antidepressants for having antipsychotic properties.
Risk of movement disorders increases with dose and duration.
Seldom used today due to safety concerns.
